BR_text.BRdescription:
There is at least one place in the GPLVM code which doesn't use the jitter_level setting:
 
 
 
 GPflow/GPflow/gplvm.py
 
 
          Line 119
       in
       b185159
 
 
 
 
 
 
  Kuu = self.kern.K(self.Z) + tf.eye(num_inducing, dtype=float_type) * 1e-6 
 
 
 
 
 
 This can lead to Cholesky failures, particularly when working in single precision see <denchmark-link:https://github.com/GPflow/GPflow/issues/466>#466</denchmark-link>
  .

comments_0.comment_text: We need to go through and see if there are other examples of this.

comments_1.comment_text:
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/alexisboukouvalas>@alexisboukouvalas</denchmark-link>
  suggests better automated test coverage on float32. I expect that would have picked this up. It would be good to do this if we can find the resources.

comments_2.comment_text:
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/alexggmatthews>@alexggmatthews</denchmark-link>
  great catch! I fixed two such occurrences in <denchmark-link:https://github.com/GPflow/GPflow/pull/465>#465</denchmark-link>
 
 test_gpvlm passes with float32
 Other tests do not (example test_ekerns fails with type error
 TypeError: Input 'y' of 'BatchMatMul' Op has type float32 that does not match type float64 of argument 'x'.)
 This does suggest we need to add float32 test coverage. Perhaps a separate issue + pull request would be more appropriate rather than trying to do this in <denchmark-link:https://github.com/GPflow/GPflow/pull/465>#465</denchmark-link>
 . Thoughts?

comments_3.comment_text:
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/GPflow/GPflow/pull/465>#465</denchmark-link>
  fixes this. However, the question of how to do better  testing is still open.
 We can close this for now?
